metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 254 to 256 of 1958; Writ Petitions Nos. 18 and 66 of 1957

facts.text: Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 254 of 1958 was a taluqdar owning several taluqdari villages in Dholka Taluka of Ahmedabad District.
In 1922-23, revision settlement of land revenue fixed aggregate land revenue for taluqdari villages at Rs. 62,627-2-6.
In 1925-26, under s.22 Gujarat Taluqdars Act, 1888, Government declared jama payable at Rs. 32,643-3-0 for 30 years from 1925-26.
Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949 passed in 1949, came into force on or about August 15, 1950.
By s.3 Abolition Act, taluqdari tenure abolished; taluqdars became occupants of lands liable to pay land revenue per Code.
After expiry of 30-year period (1955-56), talatis demanded full land revenue assessment.
Appellant filed writ petition in Bombay High Court for prohibition against enhanced revenue demand for 1955-56; dismissed on May 14, 1956 and June 15, 1956.
Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 255 of 1958 owned villages in Dholka and Dhandhuka Talukas; jama Rs. 5,734 vs settlement Rs. 14,452-11-0.
Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 256 of 1958 owned villages in Dholka Taluka; jama Rs. 21,877 vs settlement Rs. 44,551.
Writ Petition No. 66 of 1957 (appellant CA 254) re Sanad estate; jama Rs. 20,886 vs settlement Rs. 48,247-13-0; demand for 1956-57.
Writ Petition No. 18 of 1957 by Thakur Vikramsinhji of Gumph Estate; jama Rs. 16,499-4-0 vs assessment Rs. 30,223-12-0; demand 1955-56.
Appeals by special leave from Bombay High Court judgments; writ petitions under Art. 32 heard together.

legal_issues.text: Whether after expiry of 30-year jama declaration under s.22 Taluqdars Act, appellants liable only for jama per s.117R Bombay Land Revenue Code until revision settlement, or full land revenue assessment as occupants post-Abolition Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Jama ascertained and declared for 30 years was fixed at revenue settlement; by s.117R Bombay Land Revenue Code, liable only for that amount till re-settlement.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.117R Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879; s.22 Gujarat Taluqdars Act, 1888

respondent_arguments.text: Distinction between revenue settlement and ascertainment/declaration of jama under Taluqdars Act; post-Abolition Act, after 30 years, occupants liable for entire land revenue assessment.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Gujarat Taluqdars Act, 1888; Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949; Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879

court_reasoning.text: Taluqdars Act enabled survey/settlement per Code; s.22 fixed jama as aggregate survey assessments minus deductions for up to 30 years; distinct from land revenue settlement under Ch. VIII-A Code.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jama declaration not a 'settlement of land revenue' under s.117R Code; continues only till expiry.

court_reasoning.text: Abolition Act abolished tenure, made taluqdars occupants liable per Code; s.5(2)(b) saves jama declaration only so long as in force.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Post-expiry (1955-56), liable for full assessment per settlement registers.

court_reasoning.text: S.117R applies to settlements per Ch. VIII-A (operations fixing rates per groups/classes); jama under Taluqdars Act s.22 is aggregate-based arrangement, not equivalent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No continuation beyond 30 years without resettlement.

holdings.text: Declaration under s.22 Taluqdars Act expired in 1955-56; appellants liable to pay entire land revenue per settlement registers from 1955-56 as occupants.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat Taluqdars Act, 1888 (Bom. VI of 1888)
statutes_cited.relevance: Enabled survey/settlement of taluqdari estates; fixed jama as aggregate assessments minus deductions for up to 30 years; saved post-abolition till expiry.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949 (LXII of 1949)
statutes_cited.relevance: Abolished taluqdari tenure; taluqdars became occupants liable per Land Revenue Code; saved jama declarations till in force.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs land revenue settlements (fixed for 30 years, continue till revision); taluqdari lands liable per Code post-abolition; jama not a settlement thereunder.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals and writ petitions, upholding Bombay High Court; held appellants liable for full land revenue from 1955-56 after jama declaration expired.

key_quotes.text: the declaration made by the Governor in Council in 1925-26 expired in 1955-56 and the appellants became liable to pay the entire land-revenue according to the settlement registers from the year 1955-56.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The jama payable by the taluqdar was distinct from the revenue assessment of the land comprised in the taluqdari estate and they could not be equated.
key_quotes.speaker: court
